text:
the HeaderName directive does not function as it used to, or the current 
documentation is not upto-date with directions for its correct use.

HeaderName HEADER

used to prepend the contents of HEADER.html to the top if a FancyIndex directory 
listing. Current the contenst of HEADER.html are not attached. The contents of 
an ASCII file, HEADER are ignored as well.

How does one prepend HTML to the top of a directory listing?
creator: apache@lists.symmetric.net
slive@apache.org
text:
Actually, if you check the documentation for HeaderName, you will see that
the change in behavior is documented.  Including of the plain HEADER is
probably not working because you have a DefaultType that is not text/*.
You can probably fix your problem by using
HeaderName HEADER.txt
and renaming your file HEADER.txt.

I've tried it again and it still no longer works properly. 

Neither HEADER or HEADER.html are displayed as in previous apache versions.

Please visit

http://www.symmetric.net/test/

you will not see the contents of 
HEADER.html
contained in that directory, which can be verified by 

http://www.symmetric.net/test/HEADER.html

====
This server runs apache 1.3.23 and has the line

HeaderName HEADER

in the httpd.conf
creator: apache@lists.symmetric.net
apache@lists.symmetric.net
text:
It is possible I am misunderstanding the documentation. Is this statement 
correct?

"The functionality of header includes been modified eliminating the original 
capabilities completely. There is no longer a search order of [filename].html, 
then [filename]. In addition content types for headers no longer default to 
html/text and must be explicitly set."

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Yes, your statement is close to correct (although not exactly).

It is not a bug that the behavior changed.  It was done deliberately, and is fully 
documented.

If you need more help, please use a user support forum like the users
mailing list.  The bug database is not the correct place for configuration
questions.

Thanks.

creator: slive@apache.org
